body.p:
To his Excellency
Thomas E Bramlett
Governor of Kentucky

The undersigned Claiborn Lisle respectfully respectfully represents that on the 24th of May 1860 he became bound as surety in a Recognizance Bond for the appearance of Marcus Lisle at the July Term 1860 of the Clark Circuit Court Ky to answer an Indictment wherein he was charged with Gaming -- $20= being said to have been won & lost in 24 hours, the amount of that Bond being $100=

Afterwards, (during the pending of the foregoing)- to wit on the 18th of May 1861 he became further bound as the surety of said Marcus Lisle in another Recogniznace Bond, the penalty of which was $1000= for his appearance at the July Term 1861 of the aforesaid Court to answer an indictment for Gaming, the charge being that $2000= were won & lost in 24 hours

Your Petitioner further states that said Marcus Lisle appeared in said Court under the first named Indictment at the July Term 1860- and but the case was continued by the Commonwealth at the Term and also at the succeeding Terms- of November 1860= May-July & November 1861 = and at the May & July Terms 1862 = said Marcus Lisle was also present at the Apperance Term July 1861= to answer the 2nd Indictment aforesaid, but it was continued by the
Commonwealth, and was also continued at November Term 1861 and May & July and November Terms 1862 - The said Lisle being present at each of the Terms of said Court subsequent to May 1861- and inclusive of July 1862, in the fall of 1862- he went into the Confederate service and departed this life in in the fall of 1862 - & was not present at the November Term 1862 of said Court and both of the said Bonds were declared Forfeited, and at the May Term 1863 Judgments were respectively rendered against your Petitioner upon the aforesaid Bonds for $100.= and $1000 Dollars

Said Marcus Lisle always asserted and your Petitioner believed he was not guilty of the Matters charged against him he departed this life in the spring of 1863 and left no Estate, from which his surety could be indemnified in part or in whole - Your Petitioner therefore respectfully solicits your Excellency to exonerate him from the payment of the aforesaid Judgments.
Claiborne Lisle
Clark County Kentucky sworn to before me by Claiborne Lisle - Jany 26 1864
A H Buckner clk

The undersigned citisens of Clark County respectfully request that the two Judgments mentioned in the foregoing Petition may be remitted & Claiborne Lisle released from the payment thereof.
Jany 27th 1864

Ambrose G. Bush
A. N. Bush
Winchester Ky July 25 1864

I was acting as Commonwealths attorney at the November Term 1863 of the Clark Circuit Court, & the facts set forth by Claiborne Lisle Eq. in his foregoing affidavit I believe to be true, I think that this case is a meritorious one, under all the circumstances, and under the peculiar hardship of the case I recommend it for Executive Clemency.

Respectfully
Jas Flanagan

I have been acting as Sheriff of said court during the duraency of the above named cases & know that the facts are faithfully represented & think it is a case that demands if any does executive clemency

July 25th 1864
Sam G Stuart S.C.C
G W Laughlin
N. B. Gentry
A H Sympson D S

Decr 26th 1864
I recommend this
Jno. B Huston
Petition of C Lisle for Remission of Judgt in case of Marcus Lisle
I fully concur in and request that the prayer of the foregoing Petition be granted

Decr 26th 1864
Chas Eginton
Claiborne Lisles Petition
For Remission of Judgts rendered at May Term 1863 of Clark Circuit Court on Recognizance Bonds -- the Judgts being against Claiborne Lisle for the amounts severaly of $100=&$1000

Remitted
4th Jany/ 65
